Message.Title: amzn's demise has been predicted a thousand times...
Message.Msg: I still think bears are going to be in for nasty surprise later in the day, but we'll just have to wait. I see some bargain hunters coming out to play on this stock throughout the day and being around 233-235 at earnings announcement. I also predict a strong qtr that pops to 245-250 tomorrow. Retail has been strong all year, AMZN continues to build tremendous marketshare, and light expectations seem to be built into the price right now..I am predicting a small profit Q3 on strong sales with a reaffirmed Q4 number. Anyone that buys on AMZN knows the value proposition of this compnay is very strong with or without taxes. Anyone that knows sales understands the motivation of web buyers is price, availability, convenience, and trust--which AMZN is second to none. As long as e-commerce continues to gain traction, so will AMZN.

Topic.Title: amzn's demise has been predicted a thousand times...

Message.Msg: You could be right,. but I'm betting that you are not. The streets are littered with bodies of investors that were correct in their analysis and yet the market killed them. I believe Amazon, at these levels is one of those. Most of the shorts have been beaten up and are staying away from a stock that appears to me grossly overpriced. I shorted a bit at 248 and lost money when it went beyond 260. When it dropped below 240 I doubled my short. Just as investors who were long for a lengthy time are emboldened even when the market takes the stock higher than seems reasonable. People who are short, get braver (me) the further it drops. If Amazon doubled their profits this year, it would be insignificant and would barely budge the stock. If their profits fell in half, it would scare a lot of the people away from the stock. This is the first company that I have ever shorted. I've lost money on good bets in the past. I think this is a good bet to short Amazon. Until I see more profits from Amazon, irregardless of the price, I'm going short. Long-Term Sentiment Disclosure: Clueless

Topic.Title: amzn's demise has been predicted a thousand times...

Message.Msg: My friends, I think the entire premise is wrong. Online sales is not a poor business model. It's just silly to think that AMZN has higher overhead than brick and mortar retailers. The huge infrastructure spend is the drag on profits. I know Amazon well as vendor and know they are much sharper retailer than a year ago today. They automate chargebacks and take huge ad allowances. These are massive profits centers for retailers that they never touched before. I foresee this having a very large impact on the bottom line this quarter and am calling for an upside surprise. I think the 50k people they are hiring for Q4 is also a really good sign that Q4 will remain strong.

Topic.Title: margins were better than expected so we go up

Message.Msg: I have a small local company. We did that to our competition by undercutting price too. It does work, but now we have a clientele that will leave if we adjust more than 5% annually. It is going to take us a while to get to 30% margins. Luckily a bulk of our costs are not tied to inflation. Amazon might be just as lucky. They hire people and wages are staying low. So they are taking advantage of a bad economy. My thought is that amazon may get to be massive by being cheap, but it may never get to be profitable like apple. But then I see them expanding in new higher margin areas. And I realize they may be more like IBM. And get out of hardware and make their money on services. Amazon may sell goods, but they don't earn money doing it. It is more like a reason to have mainframes so they can sell technology services.

While this may have some economic impact at the margin, a Romney victory is certain to end the reign of Bernanke. Probably by this December. The markets are not pricing in that, but are just beginning to. No more Bernanke, much less easy money. Maybe the end of QE Forever. And this time, in larger chunks.

Our income tax expense was $109 million a 75% effective tax rate for the quarter and includes a one-time expense of $51 million related to the integration of Kiva Systems acquisition. Accordingly, our Q2 2012 effective tax rate is higher than both our current estimated 2012 annual effective rate and our 2011 effective tax rate. GAAP net income was $7 million or $0.01 per diluted share compared with $191 million and $0.41 per diluted share. Q2 2012 net income includes $65 million of estimated loss related to the acquisition and integration of Kiva Systems. Turning to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities decreased 1.39 billion year-over-year to 4.97 billion. Inventory increased 36% to 4.3 billion and inventory turns were 10.1 down from 11.3 turns a year ago as we expanded selection, improved in stock levels and introduced new product categories. Accounts payable increased 24% to 7.07 billion and accounts payable days decreased to 68 from 69 in the prior year. Our Q2 2012 capital expenditures were $657 million, the increase in capital expenditures reflects additional investments in support of continued business growth consisting of investments in technology infrastructure including Amazon web services and additional capacity to support our funding operations.

Message.Msg: I’ll conclude my portion of today’s call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we have seen to-date and what we believe today to be properly conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and maybe materially affected by many factors including a high level of uncertainties surrounding exchange rate fluctuations as well as the global economy consumer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand and therefore, our actual results could differ materially from our guidance. As we describe in more detail in our public filings, issues such as settling intercompany balances and foreign currencies among such subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters, and changes to our effective tax rate can all have a material effect on guidance. Our guidance further assumes that we don’t conclude any additional business acquisition, investments or settlement, record any further revision for stock-based compensation estimates, and that foreign exchange rates remain approximately where they have been recently. For the Q3 2012 we expect net sales of between 12.9 and 14.3 billion or growth between 19 and 31%. This guidance anticipates approximately 425 basis points of unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates. GAAP operating income or loss to be between 350 million loss and 50 million loss down from 79 million income in the comparable prior year period. This includes approximately $275 million for stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets. We anticipate consolidated segment operating income or loss which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expenses to be between $75 million loss and $225 million in income, or between a 129% decline and 14% decline. We expect capital expenditures including capitalized software development to be approximately $0.8 billion to $0.9 billion. These anticipated investments are driven primarily by our expectations of a continued business growth consisting of investments in technology infrastructure, including Amazon web service and additional capacity to support our fulfillment operations. We remain heads on focused on driving better customer experience through price, selection and convenience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholder. Thanks. With that, Sean, we will move to questions.

Message.Title: AMZN beat top line
Message.Msg: Net sales increased 27% to $13.81 billion in the third quarter, compared with $10.88 billion in third quarter 2011. Excluding the $348 million unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates throughout the quarter, net sales grew 30% compared with third quarter 2011. 13.81 billion + .348 billion = 14.158 billion more than 13.92 billion expected
